captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

I worry that after last week when I set out to 
widdle all over Summer Game Fest and everybody&#39;s

hopes and dreams for the future, that I let 
a little too much negativity slosh around. In

the widdle. I&#39;m not a bitter, antisocial person by 
nature, you know. I even left the house last year.

And I think we&#39;d all feel a little better if we 
took a moment to appreciate some of the positive

things in life. It&#39;s a nice sunny day. I am 
in good health. Many of the people currently

in control of the world have a decent chance 
of dying of old age in the near future. I have

a lovely smile and a vaguely symmetrical 
face. Which is not presently being stamped

again and again into a concrete pavement. And 
you know why it isn&#39;t? Because I&#39;m not playing

Shadow of the fucking Erdtree and don&#39;t 
plan to. I still haven&#39;t gotten around to

finishing base Elden Ring &#39;cos of my ongoing 
soulslike fatigue problem but you know what,

I&#39;m sick of framing that like it&#39;s a failing 
on my part. Maybe I&#39;m sick of proving myself

to you over and over again, From Software. Maybe 
if you&#39;re still judging me for not dodging away

in a direction between thirty and forty-five 
degrees between the seventh and eighth hit of

Lord Flailyarms of the Spazzout Brigade&#39;s main 
combo then you&#39;re the one who&#39;s the asshole.

Positivity, Yahtz, don&#39;t forget. Oh yeah. 
(cough) I admire the way you&#39;ve turned your

six botched penis extension surgeries to 
your advantage, Lord Flailyarms. And for

this week I&#39;m going to review a recent indie game 
I actually really liked. Cryptmaster is its name,

a first person dungeon crawler of the classic 
retro kind typified by games like Dungeon

Master on the Amiga or the Might and Magic 
games, where you glide from grid square to

grid square rotating exactly 90 degrees 
to turn and play as four heroes who&#39;ve

been sort of horrifyingly squashed together 
into a big blob of Play-doh that moves as

one. More specifically we play as four dead 
legendary heroes who get resurrected in the

depths of their subterranean resting place 
to act on behalf of the titular Cryptmaster,

who wants to guide them upwards through several 
layers of dungeon to take revenge on the surface

community that wants to keep them and every 
other mindless undead horror trapped in the

underworld because of their knee-jerk opposition 
to upward mobility in modern society, I guess.

The first and most obvious selling point for 
Cryptmaster that&#39;s on full upfront display

like an extremely interesting opening paragraph 
tattooed across a delightful pair of jubblies

is the Cryptmaster himself. Yeah, he couldn&#39;t 
more obviously be a bad guy even without the

skull face or the whole &quot;revenge on the living&quot; 
ambition, but he&#39;s such a joy to listen to I was

pretty much on his side, by the end. Yeah, why 
are the living hogging all the nice surface beach

resorts? It&#39;s just another form of racism, isn&#39;t 
it, I&#39;m not a bad person just because I smell

like a dying fart bubbling through the mushroom 
soup at Panera Bread. He&#39;s got a voice that&#39;s the

mid point between Vincent Price, Peter Lorre and 
the G-Man from Half-Life that makes all his dry,

sarcastic quips weirdly hypnotic. You remember 
that fad in the 90s for board games that came

with a VHS tape? That&#39;s what this reminds me 
of. Moving your counter along a grid while an

out of work actor with a weird face looks down 
on you the whole time taking the piss. Although

it was annoying how he kept complaining about me 
walking into corners. &quot;Are you skulking again?&quot;

NO IT&#39;S CALLED BEING THOROUGH, ASSHOLE. You 
know, like what your plastic surgeon wasn&#39;t.

But what really sold me was that in contrast 
to the old RPGs it&#39;s referencing where the

core gameplay was mainly clicking on 
things and not clicking on other things,

Cryptmaster&#39;s core gameplay mechanic is, in 
a word, Hangman. Your four dudes all have a

word hanging over them with the letters blanked 
out, you acquire letters from solving puzzles and

defeating enemies, and when you guess what their 
word is it unlocks a new memory or combat skill,

and then a new game of Hangman begins. And this 
is where my recommendation of Cryptmaster has

to have a great big qualification nailed to 
it, that is: I like it because I&#39;m the kind

of tiresome A-star in GCSE English smartarsed 
git who unironically enjoys playing Bananagrams

and gets perverse glee out of the discombobulated 
look on his 4 year old&#39;s face when he uses words

like &quot;discombobulated.&quot; If you&#39;re not into word 
puzzles then this game is gonna leave you behind

and disappear over the horizon like a deadbeat 
vampire in the face of a garlic-scented bill for

child support. Because we have a core progression 
system based around guessing the right word,

constant optional puzzles about guessing the 
right word, a conversation system based around

guessing the right word, several critical path 
boss fights based around guessing the right word,

and a core combat system based 
around, er, typing things very fast.

Yeah, this is where my second qualification flies 
across the room and beans Cryptmaster in the

skull: I don&#39;t like the combat much. It&#39;s based 
around typing the commands you learned in the

skill unlocking system to knock off enemy health 
points, stun them, buff yourselves, etc, but

when literally every other game mechanic is word 
puzzles this feels like a vicious poorly trained

dog adopted by a nice gentle family made of bacon. 
It&#39;s less about vocabulary skills and more typing

speed and desperately trying to remember which 
of the nineteen different damage-dealing commands

you&#39;ve unlocked is both appropriate for the 
situation and doesn&#39;t contain the letter A

&#39;cos you&#39;re fighting a dude with one of those 
motherfucking shields. Surely combat should&#39;ve

been about guessing the name of your opponent 
filling in letters one by one. That&#39;s on theme,

isn&#39;t it, names are power, so mid-fight you can 
go &quot;Wait, your real name&#39;s Tarquin Boobookiss?&quot;

and watch them die of shame. A shame it certainly 
is, especially since in contrast to the optional

Final Fantasy-style collectible card game 
that like all diegetic card games in RPGs I

immediately shunned like a leper clutching a Cards 
Against Humanity box, you can&#39;t avoid the combat.

So there&#39;s that, and we&#39;re playing host to a few 
other members of the &quot;gosh wouldn&#39;t it be nice&quot;

club. Gosh wouldn&#39;t it be nice if you could have 
a map of the entire floor you&#39;re on and not just

the current room. Gosh wouldn&#39;t it be nice if the 
music didn&#39;t occasionally feel a little tortured

and out of place like a King Charles spaniel in a 
tumble dryer. But for all that, there&#39;s enough to

make me like Cryptmaster, hence my earlier usage 
of the words &quot;Cryptmaster is a game that I like.&quot;

Because most importantly it&#39;s funny and clever and 
well-written. Your interface for the game world is

typing individual words, that&#39;s funny in context 
&#39;cos it&#39;s presented as as much of a sentence

your rotten undead brains can collectively string 
together. It&#39;s also explored from every possible

angle as a gameplay mechanic, AND it evokes lovely 
nostalgic memories of playing slightly dodgy text

adventures and typing word after word to figure 
out what esoteric fucking rewording of &quot;press

button&quot; the parser was looking for now. Well, not 
quite like that, it&#39;s downright impressive how

many possible inputs Cryptmaster has accounted 
for. The voice actor must&#39;ve burned through

lozenges like an industrial furnace the number 
of words he recorded on the off-chance I&#39;d type

them. &quot;Why did you say &#39;Bum Biscuits?&#39;&quot; You know 
why. Now say it again, and tell me I&#39;m pretty.
